I circulate for the information of my colleaguesa draft of the Valuation Bill. I am greatly indebtedto the President of the Board of Education who has undertaken on my behalf the supervision of thepreparation of the Bill. The present intention is to introduce the Billon Thursday, 15th I/lay, and to take the SecondReading the following Wednesday. (1) Subject to the exceptions hereafter in this Aseertain- section mentioned, the Commissioners of Inland Revenue ment of (hereinafter referred to as "the Commissioners") shall, d values. as soon as may be after every valuation date, cause a 10 valuation to be made of all land in Great Britain showing with respect to every piece of land, the land value thereof as at the valuation elate, that is to say, the amount which the fee simple in possession might have been expected to realise upon a sale in the open market 15 on that date if (a) there had not been at that date upon or in the piece of land (i) any buildings or other erections; (ii) any works of a capital nature except20 those executed more than twenty-five years before the valuation date for purposes of agriculture; (iii) anything growing on the land except trees more than twenty-five years old at the25 valuation date (not being fruit trees), hedges 134-4 A A.D. 1930-. planted more than twenty-five years before - the valuation date for purposef os agriculture, grass, and any heather, gorge, or other natural growth; (6) the purchase price had been computed without 5 taking into account- (i) the value of any minerals as such ; (ii) the cutting value of any trees; (iii) any sum which would by law or custom be payable to an outgoing tenant for tillages, 10 manure, or any improvement specified in paragraphs (20) to (28) of the First Schedule to the Agricultural Holdings Act, 1923 : (c) the sale had included the benefit in perpetuity of all rights of common and easements appendant 15 or appurtenant to the piece of land, and of any shooting rights thereover in*so far as the shooting rights were at that date in the same ownership as the land : (d) the user of the piece of land had at that date 20 been subject to no restrictions except any public rights of way or public rights of user, any right of common, any easement, and any restriction imposed by law or agreement which is binding on the owner and his successors in 25 title: (e) the piece of land had at that date been subject to no lease and free from any mortgage or charge except rates and taxes : (/) no road except any road which the occupier was 30 alone entitled to use had at that date formed part of the piece of land: Provided that notwithstanding anything in para- graphs (e) or (/) of this section, it shall be assumed for the purposes of the valuation 35 (a) that the piece of land was sold with the benefit of no greater rights of support or rights to receive compensation for damage to the surface than were vested in the owner at the valuation date; and 40 (6) that the piece of land was sold with the advan- tage afforded by the existence of any road thereon. (2) In valuing any piece of land under this section A.D. 1930. no assumption shall be made with respect to any other land, but the valuation shall be made upon the basis that all the circumstances affecting such other land 5 and everything thereon and therein were the actual circumstances at the valuation date. (3) Subject as hereinafter provided, every valuation made under this Act shall show separately the land value of every piece of land in separate occupation :10 Provided that the Commissioners may cause the land value of any two or more contiguous pieces of' land in separate occupation but owned by the same owner to be shown as if they were in the same occupation and were one piece of land.15 (4) The Commissioners shall cause all shooting rights which are, at any valuation date, in different ownership from that of the land over which they exist and all fishing rights to be valued and to be shown in every valuation made under this Act, and this Act20 shall apply accordingly as if those rights were land. (5) No valuation shall be made under this Act of any land which, at the valuation date (a) is the site of any building exclusively used for the purposes of religious worship; 25 (b) is a churchyard; (c) is a park, garden or recreation ground under the control or management of any Government Department or local authority, being a park, garden or recreation ground to which the public 30 are admitted without charge; \d) is owned by a statutory company and used in connection with their statutory undertaking and cannot be alienated by the company or appropriated to purposes unconnected with 35 their undertaking. 2. (1) As soon as may be after every valuation date Objections the Commissioners shall cause a copy of the valuation to and of every piece of land to be served on the owner thereof, appeals from and if within six months after the valuation date the occu- va ua 10ns" 40 pier or any person having any estate or interest in the piece of land (otherwise than by way only of mortgage, charge, 134 A 2 A.D; 1930. or power to create a charge)^ applies for a copy of any "*"- valuation thereof, the Commissioners shall also serve such a. copy upon him. (2) If any person entitled under the last foregoing subsection to have a copy of the valuation served on him 5 gives to the Commissioners, within the period of thirty days after the service upon him of such a copy or within such extended time as the Commissioners may within that period allow, notice in writing that. he objects to the valuation, stating the grounds of his objection, the 10 amendment he desires and his estimate of the piece of land to which the valuation relates, the Commis- sioners shall either cause the valuation to be amended in agreement with the objector or give notice to him of their refusal to agree. 15 (3) Within thirty days after the service upon any person of a notice of refusal under the last foregoing subsection, that person may appeal from the refusal to one of the panel of referees appointed under Part I of the Finance (1909-10) Act, 1910, and the decision of the 20 referee to whom the matter is referred shall, subject as hereinafter provided, be final: Provided that any party to such an appeal (including the Commissioners) aggrieved by the decision of the referee may appeal therefrom on any question of law to 25 the High Court, or, where the land value of the piece of land in respect of which the dispute arises does not, as alleged by the Commissioners, exceed five hundred pounds, to the county court for the district in which the appellant resides or the property is situate. Any party 30 shall have a right of appeal from a decision of a county court direct to the Court of Appeal. (4) If the ownership or occupation of any piece of land or any estate or interest therein is transferred from any person who has given any notice of objection or 35 commenced any appeal (either to a referee or to any court) with respect thereto under this section, the notice of objection shall be deemed to have been given or tha ' - appeal to have been commenced by the transferee. (5) The Reference Committees for England and 40 Scotland constituted by section thirty-three of the Finance (1909-10) Act, 1910, shall make rules subject to the approval of the Treasury for giving effect to the provisions of this section relating to appeals to a referee, A. and such rules shall in particular make provision- (a) as to the manner in which any such appeal is to be made : 5 (b) as to the manner in which the referee to whom any reference is to be made is to be selected : (c) for enabling the Commissioners and the appellant and any other person upon whom a copy of the valuation appealed against has been served10 under subsection (1) of this section, or any person nominated by them to appear and b6 heard : (d) for limiting the number of expert witnesses who may be heard to one on each side except where15 the referee otherwise determines : (e) as to the form in which any decision of the referee is to be given. (6) A referee may, if he thinks fit, increase any land value appealed against, and may order that the costs of 120 any appeal to him incurred by the appellant be paid by the Commissioners, and that any such costs incurred by the Commissioners be paid by the appellant, and any such order may be enforced as if it were a judgment or order of the High Court.25 (-7) Every valuation made under this Act shall, subject to the determination of any appeal, become final at the first date on which, under the foregoing provisions of this section or of any rules of court or county court rules regulating appeals under this section, no further30 objection or appeal can be made with respect thereto, and a valuation which has become final with respect to any piece of land shall remain in force until the next sub- sequent valuation thereof is made under this Act. (8) The Commissioners may cause any valuation to35 be amended at any time before it has become final, but upon any valuation being so amended it shall be deemed to be substituted for the original valuation, and the foregoing provisions of this section as to the service of copies, and (except as respects the objector, if any, in40 agreement with whom the amendment was made) as to objections and appeals, shall apply thereto accordingly. (1) The Commissioners shall keep a record show-ing, in relation to every piece of land in respect ofwhich a valuation is in force under this Act (a) the description of the piece of land; (b) the amount of the land value thereof according 5 to the valuation in force; (c) the names and addresses of the persons upon whom copies of the valuation have been served. (2) On the application of any person having anestate or interest in any piece of land, and on payment 10of such fee not exceeding [two shillings and sixpence] asthe commissioners, with the approval of the Treasury,may determine, the Commissioners shall furnish to him a copy of the valuation (if any) in force under this Actwith respect thereto. 15 4. (1) The Commissioners may by notice in writingrequire the owner, occupier or lessee of any land, or anyperson receiving or paying rent hi respect of any land,to furnish to them, within thirty days after service upon him of the notice, or within such extended time as the 20Commissioners may allow, a return showing such par-ticulars as may be within his power to furnish as to (a) the ownership, tenure, area, situation, character and use of the land : (b) any rent payable to or by him and the lease 25 under which it is payable : (c) the name and address of any person on whose behalf he pays or receives rent: (d) the consideration paid by him for his estate or (e) any other matters properly required for the purpose of the identification and valuation of the land. (2) If the owner of any land furnishes to theCommissioners his estimate of the land value of the land, 35the Commissioners shall consider it in making theirvaluation. (4) If any person fails to make a return which he is 5 required under this section to make, or wilfully omits to show in any such return any particulars within his power to furnish which he is lawfully required to show, or wilfully delays or obstructs any person authorised by the Commissioners in the exercise of any power conferred 10 on him by this section, he shall be liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding fifty pounds. 5. (1) On the occasion of any transfer on sale, or Production- of any agreement for a transfer on sale, of the fee simple to Com- of any land, or (subject as hereinafter provided) of any missioners 15 interest in land, or on the execution of any lease of any of ^f^"" land for a term exceeding fifty years, it shall be the fen^s land" duty of the transferee, ,proposed transferee, or lessee to produce to the Commissioners the instrument by means of which the transfer is effected, or agreed to be effected, or 20 the lease, as the case may be, and to furnish to the Commissioners with respect thereto particulars in accord- ance with the requirements of the Schedule to this Act, and if he fails to do so within thirty days after the execution of the instrument, he shall be liable on summary 25 conviction to a fine not exceeding ten pounds : Provided that this subsection shall not apply (a) on the transfer on sale of any interest under a lease granted for a term not exceeding fifty years,or of any mortgage, or of any incorporeal 30 hereditament, or of any interest in expectancy other than a reversion expectant nn the determination of a lease; or (b) with respect to any instrument which is a mining lease or an assignment of a mining35 lease; or - (c) with respect to any instrument which relates solely to a grave or a right of burial. (2) Notwithstanding anything in section twelve of the Stamp Act, 1891, no instrument required by this40 section to be presented to the Commissioners shall be deemed for the purposes of section fourteen of that Act to be duly stamped unless it is stamped with a stamp A.D. 1930. denoting that the provisions of this section have been complied with : Provided that where any agreement for a transfer has been stamped in accordance with this subsection, it shall not be necessary so to stamp the instrument of transfer 5 made in pursuance of the agreement. 6. (1) Any document issued on behalf of the Commissioners under this Act may be served on any person by delivering it to him or sending it by post to his usual or last known address, or, if his address is not 10 known and cannot reasonably be ascertained, by leaving the document addressed to him with the occupier of any land to which the document relates or of any premises on such land, or, if no such occupier can be found, by causing it to be posted in some conspicuous place on the 15 land. (2) Any copy of a valuation signed by a secretary " or assistant secretary of the Commissioners and produced by any officer of the Commissioners shall be received in evidence, and any such copy purporting to be so signed 20 as aforesaid shall be deemed to be so signed and to be a true copy unless the contrary is proved. (3) The provisions of the Inland Revenue Regulation Act, 1890, as amended by section thirty-eight of the Finance Act, 1896, shall apply as if this Act were an Act 25 relating to inland revenue and as if any matter or thing to which this Act relates were a matter or thing relating to inland revenue and as if any person employed by the Commissioners of Inland Revenue for the purposes of this Act were a person employed in relation to inland 30 revenue.Interpreta- 7. (1) In this Act unless the context otherwisetion. requires the following expressions have the meanings hereby respectively assigned to them, that is to say " Agriculture " means the use of land as agricultural 35 land as defined hj subsection (2) of section two of the Rating and Valuation (Apportionment) Act, 1928 : " Lease " includes an underlease and an agreement for a lease or underlease, but does not include 40 any mortgage and " lessee " has a corresponding- meaning :Supple-mentaryprovisions. 1015202530"Minerals" includes all minerals and substances A:B. l'.rM). in or under land, obtainable by underground or by surface working :" Mortgage" and " possession " have the same meanings as in the Law of Property Act, 1925 :" Occupier " in relation to any land not in occupation means the person entitled to the occupation thereof :" Owner," in relation to any land let under a lease granted for a term exceeding fifty years, means the lessee under the lease, or, if there are two or more such leases, the lessee under the last created under-lease, and in relation to any other land, means the person entitled to the fee simple in possession; and "own" and " ownership" have corresponding mean- ings :" Statutory company " means any persons author- isecl by any special Act to construct, work, or carry on any railway, canal, inland navigation, dock, harbour, tramway, gas, electricity, water, or other public undertaking; " statutory under- taking " means such an undertaking as afore- said; and ".special Act" includes any order having the force of an Act of Parliament :" Valuation date" means, as respects the first- valuation made under this Act the date of the commencement of this Act, as respects the second valuation so made the seventh anniver- sary of that date, and as respects every subsequent valuation the fifth anniversary of the last previous valuation date :" Works " includes neither buildings nor erections nor works for the reclamation of land or for the protection thereof from flooding, but in- cludes fences (which shall not be deemed to be erections) and field drains and ditches. (2) This Act applies to land owned or occupied bythe Crown. 134 B Short title 9. This Act may be cited as the Land Valuation Act, 1930. A.D. 1030. 8.Applicationto Scotland. SCHEDULE. a.d. 1930. PARTICULARS TO BE FURNISHED ON PRODUCTION OF INSTRUMENTS OF TRANSFER. Together with any instrument produced to the Commis- 5 sioners in accordance with the provisions of section four of this Act, there shall be furnished to the Commissioners either (a) a copy of the instrument and a document showing (i) so far as they are not set out in the copy,10 particulars of the estate or interest transferred, including, where the transaction is the assignment or grant of a lease or the transfer of a fee simple subject to a lease, the term of the lease, the date of the commencement of the term, and the rent15 reserved; and (ii) the signature and address of the transferee or lessee or of the person presenting the particulars on his behalf; or (6) the particulars of the following matters : (i) the description of the instrument; (ii) the date of the instrument; (iii) the names and addresses of the transferor and transferee or lessor and lessee; (iv) the estate or interest transferred, including, where the transaction is the assignment or grant of a lease or the transfer of a fee simple subject to a lease, the term of the lease, the date of the com- mencement of the term, and the rent reserved; (v) the consideration, if any, other than the rent shown under the last paragraph, showing separately any capital payment, any mortgage debt released, any mortgage debt covenanted to be paid, any periodical payment (including any charge) covenanted to be paid, any terms surrendered, and any land exchanged; (vi) the situation and boundaries of the land to be identified, including any dimensions stated in the instrument, and, if necessary for the identification of the land or the definition of the boundaries thereof, a plan; 134 C2025303540 i(vii) minerals, sporting rights, timber or easementsreserved, any restrictions, covenants, or conditionsaffecting the value of the estate or interest transferredor granted; (viii) the signature and address of the transferee for lessee or of the person presenting the particularson his behalf.
